did.unittitle: Philadelphia Museum of Art Education Division records

bioghist.p: The Division of Education was firmly established in 1939. Under several Chiefs during the years, the Division has organized tours, lectures, classes and events, published guides and slides of the collection, and has helped prepare exhibitions.

scopecontent.p: The "Chief, Division of Education Records" series refers to the title given to the staff member who headed the Museum's educational programs during the 1940s and 1950s. The series consists of subject and correspondence files generated by E.M. Benson and his successor John M. Canaday. A draft folder-level inventory is available in the Archives. The “Exhibition” series consists of files documenting exhibitions hels at the Museum and include correspondence, publicity, and signage The "Photographs" series primarily depict children in a variety of art studio classes. Most appear to date from the 1940s. There are also some photographs of special exhibitions, particularly the puppet program, of works of art produced in the classes, and of lecture groups in various galleries. Some of the photographs are captioned or identified on the verso. While the photographs of this series document some of the department's programs and activities, the photographs in "Teaching Materials," were compiled, as the title suggests, as visual aids in classes and lectures featuring works of art. The photographs, which are mounted, primarily depict paintings, and are grouped by collection name or general genres, such as "sculpture" and "Persian miniatures." Each has an identifying caption. The series also includes oversized reproduction prints of paintings, prints and drawings. The original folder titles identify the prints by artist or by a more general description, such as "Drawings by Old Masters" or "German schools, 15th and 16th century." Some of the folders appear to be misidentified. "Film Programs" (1962-1982), include schedules, budgets, and printed material. "Miscellaneous printed material," consists of a sampling of brochures and other mailers produced by the department that describe the Museum's public programs from approximately 1940 to 1980. Other series focus on the special programs and exhibitions produced by the Education staff. To compliment and expand upon many of the Museum's special exhibitions, the Education department would concurrently run related school and public programs. These efforts are the subject of, "Special Exhibitions," which consists of 7.5 linear feet of material. The programs documented in this series were held from 1939 to 1988, and cover a wide range of arts, from Pennsylvania folk to African art. "Annual Reports" includes copies of the Museum's Annual reports issued from 1985 to 1995. “Guide Training” contains materials related to Park houses, PMA guides, and School guides. The "Family Programs" (1987-1999) series consists of general teaching materials, brochures, and the files of Julie Rogers (1979-1981) and Any Jared (1987-1989). Materials related to the Department’s "Distance Learning" program (1999-2004, n.d.) include lesson confirmations and evaluations, materials related to distance learning programs at other institutions, and materials on VASTweb. Scrapbooks of printed materials (1932-1969) round out the collection.
